subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules

That's the ticket. We both really wanted to know the truth no matter who wa=
s right or wrong - we weren't arguing just for the sake of it.

Just FYI-It=
 isn't that I am against using the scientific method. In fact I do employ i=
t when investigating anything, just for my own satisfaction. I want to beli=
eve my evidence, so I have to be as scientific about it as possible, but no=
t so I can prove it to anyone else, just myself.

In Frank's case, maybe he=
 doesn't want or need to prove it to himself scientifically, and that is fi=
ne too.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogro=
ups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 5:55 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File=
 uploading rules





        Who to go to?  The scientific method!

      =
  This was a good example of how a couple people, with differing opinions b=
ut open minds, can follow an objective methodology to root out the right an=
swer.

        1) Observation.  We heard (indirectly) that someone has seen=
 wave files experience lossy compression when sent through email clients.

=
        2) Hypothesis.  The theory is that the email client, and/or email s=
ervers, perform lossy compression on their attachments for wave files.

   =
     3) Predictions.  Based on this hypothesis, this should be observable b=
y attaching and sending large waves files through some email servers, and c=
omparing both the originals, and the final files.  If original files and th=
e final files should experience differences in contents.

        4) Experi=
ments.  We sent different files, of different sizes, through different clie=
nts and servers.  

        5) Analyze results.  We compared the originals =
at the byte level, and found no loss.

        6) Interpret.  No compressio=
n was observed in our tests, and so no compression is being done with the s=
ervers and clients and environments in which we tested.  This does not make=
 any claims about other tests or environments, but provides good testing an=
d predictions for what would be expected based on our tests.

        Witho=
ut this kind of method, we could have just gone back and forth giving subje=
ctive or emotional arguments, with no real evidence.  But following this ki=
nd of method, we get to what we really both wanted: reliable interpretation=
 of phenomenon.

        And this doesn't mean we need to close the books f=
orever.  More prediction, more experiments, more results can be tried by mo=
re people, published, and reproduced.  The body of knowledge then grows wid=
er, deeper, and more reliable.

        This is why I push the scientific m=
ethod even with EVP studies, even while others continue subjective or emoti=
onal arguments: to improve the study, and to allow progress to be made by a=
s many people as possible.





        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrom=
bie <april@...> wrote:


          From: April Abe=
rcrombie <april@...>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-I=
TC] File uploading rules
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Da=
te: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 4:23 PM



          Sweet! Now I know who to go =
to ;)

            ----- Original Message ----- 
            From: Rj 
    =
        To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 200=
9 4:56 PM
            Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


       =
           Yep, that's exactly what that comparison does.  It compares each=
 and every byte (all their 
                  bits) from file to file.  If =
the same bytes are in both files, in the same places, they are the same.  O=
ne tiny little difference, and it tells you.

                  --- On Sun,=
 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:

=

                    From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresear=
ch. com>
                    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
  =
                  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                    Date: Su=
nday, May 10, 2009, 3:42 PM



                    You can actually tell if=
 the bytes themselves are different? If so, that would definitely satisfy m=
e that everything was the same.

                      ----- Original Messa=
ge ----- 
                      From: Rj 
                      To: EVP-ITC=
@yahoogroups .com 
                      Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 4:32 PM=

                      Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTIO=
N JON


                            If the audio had been resampled, you co=
uld expect less bytes, or different bytes, but not the same number of the s=
ame bytes.  That's why comparing the bytes in both files can rule that out,=
 if no changes are found.



                            --- On Sun, 5/10/0=
9, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


      =
                        From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostres=
earch. com>
                              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploa=
ding rules-ATTENTION JON
                              To: EVP-ITC@yahoogro=
ups .com
                              Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 3:27 PM
=



                              Yeah-I know about the file size comparison=
. Obviously if the file size became smaller, we know for sure there has bee=
n loss, except if the file had been saved to a lossless compression type, s=
uch as from RAW to TIFF in photo files.

                              I ju=
st don't fully trust the bit comparison because I don't trust that the byte=
s haven't been resampled using interpolation, such as we discussed earlier.=
 But that is largely because I have no clue at that level of things what is=
 actually going on.

                              All I know about this I =
know from Graphic Design experience and working with photo files, so I only=
 have that knowledge to use to compare. I no nothing about actual programmi=
ng language, Unix, or stuff like that.

                              April=


                                ----- Original Message ----- 
           =
                     From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@=
yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 200=
9 4:13 PM
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploa=
ding rules-ATTENTION JON


                                They are not nec=
essarily the same bytes, but I was proposing a quick check just to see if t=
he files were in the same ballpark.  Look at it the other way: if the numbe=
r of bytes were DIFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD changed, and you c=
ould stop testing.  But if the number of bytes are the same, it tends to in=
dicate the files are likely the same, but you still need a low level file c=
omparison to be sure.

                                My method is to comp=
are the files using the CMP command in unix.  There are many programs to co=
mpare files, but you have to be careful not to use one that does a line-by-=
line compare (or a comparison meant for text files), since text files can b=
e different at a low level, but look essential the same in an editor (becau=
se of the way spaces and tabs and new lines work between editors and platfo=
rms).

                                But anyway, the way to compare is wi=
th a program that can compare binary files, not text files.


             =
                   --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombi=
egh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                From: April =
Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                        =
        Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
         =
                       To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                       =
         Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:42 PM



                           =
     So if the number of bytes match then they are the same bytes? See wher=
e my confusion comes in?

                                How does one do a=
 bit-level comparison? Is there a program that does that, or is there some =
way of comparison by looking at the file's properties?

                   =
             ----- Original Message ----- 
                                =
From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
   =
                             Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 3:35 PM
           =
                     Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION =
JON


                                A file's content, it's integrity, is =
simply the bytes (and their bits) in the file.  If the file's content integ=
rity is changed, that is, by definition, changing the bytes.  If the bytes =
in there are not changed, then that integrity has not changed.

           =
                     It is possible to mess with other things about a file =
(like its name, its suffix, or its ownership) but this does not effect the =
contents, and so would not affect that integrity, or the sound of the file =
(assuming you could read it at all after changing the ownership, or the suf=
fix, etc).

                                When you do your tests, if you =
cannot do a bit level comparison, I would recommend at least checking the f=
ile sizes.  If they are identical, there is a very high probability that th=
e content has not changed.




                                --- On Sun, =
5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


=
                                From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombieg=
h ostresearch. com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] =
File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
                                To: EVP-=
ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May 10, =
2009, 2:28 PM



                                Admittedly I do not know m=
uch about bit-level comparisons, what they can or can't show so I will have=
 to leave that to you. I have doubts because I worry once a file's integrit=
y has been messed with, I wonder that even though the bits match, maybe tha=
t doesn't mean they are the same quality as the original. I really don't kn=
ow though what is possible or impossible when it comes to this area.

     =
                           "It is probably possible to set up an email comp=
ression scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setu=
p does not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. =
From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual=
."

                                The problem I have is that not just fro=
m Jon, but I have heard it from other people, and a professional and they a=
ll said that loss is possible. From all that, my conclusion was that maybe =
in some cases loss was possible.

                                However, =
your arguments do put doubt back into my mind, which pisses me off, because=
 I had originally argued feverishly for no loss, then I heard different fro=
m different sources and decided to do what I thought was the right thing by=
 contacting a third party professional. So after all that, I decided I was =
licked and had to eat crow.

                                Now I am back =
at square one, from the other side LOL!!! Computer people have been wrong i=
n the past.


                                "It is probably possible to s=
et up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My=
 tests show my setup does not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, w=
e can do that too. From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment wo=
uld be very unusual."

                                I have not tested it=
 from my computer, as I haven't had any problems with loss. I would really =
like to have Jon work with us on this, because he was the original person w=
ho told me I was wrong.

                                But I will test it=
 from my side. I will send a wav file to one of my other addresses. Then I =
will download and compare. If I think I hear a difference, then maybe I can=
 have you do a bit-level comparison on the files.

                        =
        Either way, I am going to get to the bottom of this.



           =
                     ----- Original Message ----- 
                        =
        From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .=
com 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:59 PM
   =
                             Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-AT=
TENTION JON


                                Yes you can tell loss of qual=
ity by a bit-level comparison.  An audio file is just a file of bytes, that=
 is later interpreted by an audio player.  Two files with the exact same co=
ntents, whether they are audio or image or a dababase or an exe, are indist=
inguishable from each other.  That is, if I copied the contents of one to a=
 new file, and the contents of the other to a new file, and asked you which=
 file each came from, there would be no way to tell.  Even the audio player=
 could not tell.  The data is identical, and so the sound (or the picture, =
etc) would be identical.

                                Yes I did listen =
to the results, but that is not the best test (they sounded identical, but =
that is a subjective opinion).  The real test is compring the contents.  Id=
entical contents means indentical data, means identical audio.

           =
                     It is probably possible to set up an email compression=
 scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does =
not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From wh=
at I see, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual.


   =
                             --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@=
abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                Fr=
om: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
              =
                  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON=

                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
             =
                   Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1:50 PM



                 =
               I have not personally experienced the loss myself. Jon from =
this list is the one who originally told me about it. I have also heard of =
it happening to a few other people. After my conversation with Jon, I talke=
d to a computer professional, and he told me that you can experience loss i=
n attached files.

                                I don't know if you woul=
d be able to tell loss of quality in an audio file with a bit-level compari=
son. Just because the data has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it is pe=
rfect.

                                Did you listen to the before and af=
ter results?

                                Jon-Please relay your experie=
nce with the loss of quality on emailed files.


                          =
      ----- Original Message ----- 
                                From: R=
j 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
          =
                      Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
                  =
              Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


               =
                 I can't vouch for your computer or servers, but I just did=
 some tests, and sent a 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once all=
owing compression, and once turning it off.   I was able to verify that one=
 was compressed and one was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived at=
 Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of th=
e original, and the ones sent around email.  They were all identical, which=
 indicates lossless compression.

                                If you ha=
ve a file you'd like me to test for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take =
someone's word for how your server's work, without testing them yourself.

=


                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <a=
pril@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                             =
   From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
         =
                       Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
        =
                        To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                      =
          Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 12:50 PM



                         =
       For executables, you may be right. However, for wav files, the compr=
ession during email is not loss less. 

                                I u=
sed to think as you do, in that the emailed attachment of a wav file would =
not loose anything. After a lengthy discourse with another member here, I l=
earned that I was wrong. The reason why I did not realize it in the first p=
lace is that when I would email a wav file, I would intentionally keep it i=
n very small segments, to keep file size down. This was just for ease of tr=
ansfer. But because of this, I had not experienced any noticeable loss.

  =
                              Now it may be in some cases, depending on the=
 servers or what have you that the file goes through, that the loss may be =
less or more. But once the attachment is downloaded, the quality has been f=
ound to be less then the original wav.

                                Aga=
in though you can only really tell when the wav file is large.

           =
                     ----- Original Message ----- 
                        =
        From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .=
com 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
   =
                             Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


=
                                The kind of compression that occurs during =
an email attachment is "lossless": it compress the file cleverly without lo=
sing information.  For example, if I had a program in some .exe files, and =
I sent it over email, it could compress it.  But if it lost even one bit, t=
he resulting exe file would not execute again after it was uncompressed on =
the other side.

                                This kind of compression d=
oes things like looking for common patterns in the file, and replacing them=
 with a token.  A rough example would be if it found "Howdy Neighbor" in a =
file 20 times, it could replace all the occurances with say $HN1.  And also=
 write a little dictionary in there someplace that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neigh=
bor".

                                When the file gets to its destinatio=
n it can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "How=
dy Neighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it only=
 needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

                       =
         Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not lossless.  Depending on t=
he level of compression, some level of data is lost, and so cannot be recov=
ered or reconstructed later.

                                Rick



     =
                           --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@ab=
ercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


                                From=
: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                =
                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
               =
                 To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                             =
   Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



                                =
Another thing:

                                I recently found this out. =
When you email a file, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the email=
 filtering process will actually compress the file automatically.

        =
                        So even if you have attached a wav. file, it will l=
oose resolution over the email process. It will not sound exactly the same =
as the original wav. file. How much it differs depends on the size of the f=
ile you are attaching. If it is a very large file, it will sound much diffe=
rent.

                                The only exception to this is if the=
 wav. file is small enough that the filtering process will ignore it. It ha=
s to be pretty small though, like under 1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the =
threshold).

                                The best way to share files ov=
er the internet if you want them as close to the original as possible is to=
 upload them directly to a website.

                                ----- =
Original Message ----- 
                                From: Rj 
         =
                       To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                      =
          Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                             =
   Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules



                         =
       Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces it.  Imagine tak=
ing a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning to add levels or pixeliz=
ation to the picture.  Soon, you would not be able to tell there were flowe=
rs there at all.  You would see a lot of colored blocks.

                 =
               Or in the other direction, imagine you are looking at a comp=
etely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a complete screen of truely =
random static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a while, you would again start =
to see colored blocks.

                                What's happening is=
 that it is processing an area of the image, taking (for instance) the aver=
age value of that entire area, and replacing all the blocks in that area wi=
th the average.  In video processing, this would result in a field of multi=
-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish bloc=
k, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe replace =
all the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.  If you did no=
t know beforehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell whether =
your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky with c=
louds, or a random bunch of pixels.

                                It wor=
ks the same with the sound files.  Taking something as complex as speech, a=
nd replacing frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the farther =
you go, until you head strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the same to=
 random static will eventually produce the same thing.  And random fluctuat=
ing square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at least, you could have =
fun sharing with each other what you thing they 'sound like'.





        =
                        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo=
.com> wrote:


                                From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabe=
a@ yahoo.com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File u=
ploading rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com=

                                Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:29 AM


    =
                            I always save the whole file in wav format then=
 do my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for analysis. 

             =
                   As far as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos to=
 say that isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a form of wh=
ite noise. I seem to remember some experiments done with blank tapes/film, =
no recording done yet there were voices/images there. I find it all interes=
ting.

                                Just a thought. Ok off to work now!
=
                                Misty

                                --- =
On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:


                        =
        From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
                                Subj=
ect: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To:=
 EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, May=
 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


                                Be a bit careful of f=
ormats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the sounds though. =
  While some formats (like wav) can store the audio very close to the way i=
t was recorded, formats like mp3 compress the file, and in so doing lose so=
me of the sonic details.  This may not be a big deal in music, where the au=
dio is fairly clear to begin with.  But with sound sources with a lot of no=
ise (like evps), this can not only obscure any real sounds, but pixelize no=
n-sounds (like white noise) and make them start to sound like speech.

    =
                            So mp3 might be good for sharing the data, once=
 you've already formed an opinion based on an analysis of the wav file.  Bu=
t mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It can lead to many false posi=
tives and misinterpretations.

e: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM

                                 You will get the hang of it. Kristen=
 is right thats how you save it. For most softwares its under save as or ex=
port as. If you still have trouble use one of the links I posted to help ya=
 out.

                                Misty

    <TBODY>
    <TR>
      <TD vAlign=3Dtop=
>Who to go to?  The scientific method!<BR><BR>This 
        was a good=
 example of how a couple people, with differing opinions but 
        open =
minds, can follow an objective methodology to root out the right 
        a=
nswer.<BR><BR>1) Observation.  We heard (indirectly) that someone 
   =
     has seen wave files experience lossy compression when sent through ema=
il 
        clients.<BR><BR>2) Hypothesis.  The theory is that the ema=
il 
        client, and/or email servers, perform lossy compression on thei=
r 
        attachments for wave files.<BR><BR>3) Predictions.  Based o=
n this 
        hypothesis, this should be observable by attaching and send=
ing large 
        waves files through some email servers, and comparing bo=
th the 
        originals, and the final files.  If original files and=
 the final 
        files should experience differences in contents.<BR><BR=
>4) 
        Experiments.  We sent different files, of different sizes=
, through 
        different clients and servers.  <BR><BR>5) Analyze =
results.  
        We compared the originals at the byte level, and fo=
und no 
        loss.<BR><BR>6) Interpret.  No compression was observe=
d in our 
        tests, and so no compression is being done with the serve=
rs and clients 
        and environments in which we tested.  This doe=
s not make any claims 
        about other tests or environments, but provi=
des good testing and 
        predictions for what would be expected based =
on our 
        tests.<BR><BR>Without this kind of method, we could have ju=
st gone back 
        and forth giving subjective or emotional arguments, w=
ith no real 
        evidence.  But following this kind of method, we =
get to what we 
        really both wanted: reliable interpretation of phen=
omenon.<BR><BR>And 
        this doesn't mean we need to close the books fo=
rever.  More 
        prediction, more experiments, more results can b=
e tried by more people, 
        published, and reproduced.  The body =
of knowledge then grows wider, 
        deeper, and more reliable.<BR><BR>T=
his is why I push the scientific 
        method even with EVP studies, eve=
n while others continue subjective or 
        emotional arguments: to impr=
ove the study, and to allow progress to be 
        made by as many people =
as possible.<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On 
        <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April =
Abercrombie 
        <I><april@abercrombiegh<WBR>ostresearch.<WBR>com&gt=
;</I></B>

                                <TD vAlign=
=3Dtop>They are not necessarily the same 
                                b=
ytes, but I was proposing a quick check just to 
                          =
      see if the files were in the same 
                                ba=
llpark.  Look at it the other way: if the 
                           =
     number of bytes were DIFFERENT, than you'd know 
                     =
           the files HAD changed, and you could stop 
                     =
           testing.  But if the number of bytes are 
                 =
               the same, it tends to indicate the files are 
              =
                  likely the same, but you still need a low level 
        =
                        file comparison to be sure.<BR><BR>My method is 
  =
                              to compare the files using the CMP command in=
 
                                unix.  There are many programs to co=
mpare 
                                files, but you have to be careful no=
t to use one 
                                that does a line-by-line comp=
are (or a 
                                comparison meant for text files)=
, since text 
                                files can be different at a l=
ow level, but look 
                                essential the same in a=
n editor (because of the 
                                way spaces and ta=
bs and new lines work between 
                                editors and =
platforms).<BR><BR>But anyway, the 
                                way to =
compare is with a program that can 
                                compare=
 binary files, not text 
                                files.<BR><BR><BR>=
--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April

                                <TD vA=
lign=3Dtop>A file's content, it's integrity, 
                             =
   is simply the bytes (and their bits) in the 
                           =
     file.  If the file's content integrity is 
                      =
          changed, that is, by definition, changing the 
                  =
              bytes.  If the bytes in there are not 
                 =
               changed, then that integrity has not 
                      =
          changed.<BR><BR>It is possible to mess with 
                    =
            other things about a file (like its name, its 
                =
                suffix, or its ownership) but this does not 
              =
                  effect the contents, and so would not affect 
           =
                     that integrity, or the sound of the file 
            =
                    (assuming you could read it at all after 
             =
                   changing the ownership, or the suffix, 
                =
                etc).<BR><BR>When you do your tests, if you 
              =
                  cannot do a bit level comparison, I would 
              =
                  recommend at least checking the file 
                   =
             sizes.  If they are identical, there is a 
              =
                  very high probability that the content has not 
         =
                       changed.<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
        =
                        5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                       =
         <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                         =
       com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
                                <BLOCKQUO=

hat to you. I have doubts 
                                because I worry =
once a file's integrity has been 
                                messed wi=
th, I wonder that even though the bits 
                                mat=
ch, maybe that doesn't mean they are the same 
                            =

ion was that maybe in some cases 
                                loss was =

er,

                                back at square one, from the other side LO=
L!!!

ile, and asked you which file each came from,
